results.justification: The document clearly states the research aims to integrate ML, XAI, and clustering to understand the relationship between learning behaviors and achievement, considering person-level factors. "Our study presents a novel approach incorporating explainable AI (XAI) and clustering..."
The '4.2 Analysis Pipeline' section provides a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, from data generation to cluster comparison.

The document states: "proficiency tests, questionnaire items, and hyper-parameter grids for all trained ML models are listed on the OSF: https://osf.io/2v9gf/?view_only= 2154581235ac46bb8ce719e82168f793."
While data is linked on OSF, the raw data itself isn't explicitly stated to be available. The link points to supplementary materials, not necessarily the raw dataset.

The document describes the variables used (e.g., English proficiency score, person-level factors) and mentions a detailed description of feature engineering in a prior work [17]."A detailed description of the feature engineering process can be found in [ 17]."

The '4.1 Data Set' and '4.1.2 Procedure and Study Design' sections fully describe the data collection methods, including the ITS used (FeedBook), the study design (cluster-randomized controlled field trial), and data sources (proficiency tests, questionnaires, behavioral trace data).

The document states: "All preprocessing steps, as well as the ML and XAI analysis, were conducted with Python 3.8 using scikit-learn 1.3.2 [42], xgboost 1.6.2 [13], and shap 0.41.0 [33]." and links to the OSF where hyperparameter grids are available.
The document does not explicitly state that the full analysis code is shared in an open repository. It mentions the tools used but not the code itself.
The document mentions that the feature engineering process is described in a prior work [17], implying code or a description of the code used for data preparation is available.

Statistical tests (MANOVA), models (linear regression, lasso regression, support vector regression, decision tree, random forest, XGBoost), and assumptions are described throughout the '4.2 Analysis Pipeline' section.
Effect sizes, RMSE, MAE, and explained variance are reported in Table 2. P-values are mentioned in the context of statistical significance (α < .05).
The study is primarily quantitative. While there's interpretation of results, it's not a qualitative analysis with subjective context in the traditional sense.
The study is primarily quantitative and does not involve data coding or qualitative analysis.
Results are clearly presented in tables (e.g., Table 2, Table 3) and text, with descriptions of cluster characteristics and statistical comparisons.
The '6.2 Limitations and Future Work' section explicitly discusses limitations related to the system, data collection, sample characteristics, and modeling choices.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on the Open Science Foundation or any other preregistration platform.
